advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 64 BITS IN 1983?</strong></font><br><blockquote>After the optimistic 36 Mhz. speed, here is the 64 bits processing power... with 8 bits/Z80 cards. Here also, the 64 bits 'power' is obtained by putting eight 8 bits cards together in the case.<br> Not a very honest way to sell a computer that is no more than a classic S-100 / Z80 based system with some multi-user capabilities.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> (FUNNY) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>... from a promotional brochure</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL GUIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO 7, the family computer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.K. AD (OCT. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The letters you send speak volumes for your company's image. Scrappy typing, untidy layouts and poor spelling announce that you're less than professional outfit.<br> Whereas beautifully presented correspondence shows quite clearly that you're a company to be reckoned with.<br> Now Amstrad's new wordprocessor with daisywhell printer and spellcheck facility means that any company can produce superb quality letters, reports and documents.<br> With the minimum of effort and for a minimal outlay.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''It's time''<br> ''ATMOS from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juan Antonio Maestre for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, NOV. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID SITUATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>A translation would be : "the 10 years old and more children appreciate quickly the computing principles and have a lot of fun with their ZX-80" <br><br> So they say...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Oric opens a full world to you"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV.1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"don't touch my Amstrad gaming system !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OHIO BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sharp 1211 advert from ILLEL, a french computer seller</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SEEQUA AD (JUN. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>First advert of the Model 100.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOL PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><u>Sol Systems price list (january 1977)</u></b> <br><br> (K) = Kit (A) = Assembled<br><br> <b>Sol Terminal Computers<br> </b>SOL-PC Single board (K) <b> $475</b><br> SOL-10 (K) <b> $795</b><br> SOL-20 (K) <b> $995</b> <br><br> <b>Memory Modules</b> <br> PROM Resident Assembly Language (A) <b>$425</b><br> Interpretive Simulator (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Text Editing (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Erasable PROM module (K) <b>$65 </b>(A) <b>$89</b> <br> 4 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b> $159</b> (A) <b> $195</b><br> 8 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b>$295</b> (A) <b>$375</b><br> 16 Kb. Dynamic Ram (A) <b>$529</b> <br><br> <b>Interface Modules</b><br> Parallel / Serial I/O Module (K) <b>$149</b> (A) <b>$199</b><br> System cassette interface (K) <b>$87 </b> (A) <b>$119</b><br> Video Display Module (K) <b>$199 </b> (A) <b>$295</b><br> <br> <b>Mass Storage System</b><br> Helios II Disk system (K) <b>$1895</b> (A) <b>$2295</b><br><br> <b>Software<br> </b>(C) = Cassette (P) = Paper tape<br> Basic 5 (P) <b>$19.95</b><br> 8K Basic (C) <b>$29</b> (P) <b>$37</b><br> New 8080 Focal (C) <b>$14.50</b> <br> Trek 80 Video game (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> GamePack 1 (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> MathPack Video calculator (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> Assembler (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> ALS 8 (C) <b>$35</b> (P) <b>$45</b> </blockquote>

computer.description:
The following description comes from www.atariHQ.com website, especially the Stunt Cycle dedicated page :
"Considered by many collectors as the coolest of the dedicated (non-cartridge) Atari home consoles, Stunt Cycle allowed aspiring Evel Knievel wannabes the joy of performing knarly stunts -- without the risk of breaking one's neck. Tons of tricks to pull off here, from jumping cars and buses to flying over wide canyons. Based on the coin-op of the same name.
The original coin-op had been released in 1975 to take advantage of the then popular motorcycle stuntman Evel Knievel. Originally a motorcycle salesman who began doing stunts to draw attention to his store, by the early 70's he was a household name. Atari's coin-op attempted to capture the feel and fun of the stunt jumping Evel Knievel was famous for, and was a mild success.
Now under Warner control and hoping to ride the crest of the Evel Knievel toy craze (even though it was near it's end), Atari decided to release a home version of Stunt Cycle. Originally codenamed "Stunt Debbie" during it's design, Atari Stunt Cycle (Model C-450) was released in 1977. Unfortunately 1977 also happened to be the year known for the death of the "dedicated" consoles, as the Fairchild Video Entertainment system had been released the year before. Known as the first programmable cartridge based console, it caused the "pong" market to collapse as the many pong knockoff manufacturers saw "the end" coming. Subsequently, they dumped their merchandise at clearance prices in an effort to get out with at least some money - unknowingly sparking what is known as the "first great video game crash". Atari didn't help Stunt Cycle's chances by releasing no less than 6 new pong consoles that year AND debuted it's own programmable console - the now famous Atari Video Computer System (2600).
As with all Atari dedicated consoles, Sears released it's own Atari manufactured version of the Stunt Cycle that same year. Called the Sears Telegames Motocross (Model 99748), Sears tried to remedy the flood problem by combining it's Ultra Sports IV console (equivalent to Atari's Pong Sports Doubles) console with Stunt Cycle. The result was a hybrid system that allowed you to plug in 4 pong paddles and play 16 different pong games along with the normal Stunt Cycle games.
Unfortunately, the plan didn't help Sears either. Besides the dedicated console crash, Evel and his toys were on the way out by the late 1970's due to his decreasing popularity after a series of failed stunts "
Commercial text taken from the system box:
"Jump 32 buses in your living room! - Converts any TV into a racetrack with competition event for all members of the family. - Designed with different skill levels, for handicapping. Always challenging, even for experts. - Once you get the hang on it, go for it and put the difficulty switch in the "PRO" position. Be careful."
computer.name: Stunt Cycle (model SC-450)
